results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film begins with Dorothy, Karen and Stuart relaxing around the family Christmas tree, 1984 and moves onto family activities in the backyard. There are two extended family weddings and some wonderful fashion from the early 1980s.

The highlight of the film is Karen’s 21st birthday where we see the traditional table for the presents to be displayed before Karen proudly poses for the camera in front of her new car.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 Dorothy, Karen and Stuart chatting, whilst seated around their Christmas tree at home
00:00:23:00 Karen in some fantastic embroidered trousers with a boyfriend, Dorothy and Stuart in the garden at home
00:00:35:00 family barbeque in the backyard
00:00:53:00 classic 1970s and 1980s style glassware
00:02:33:00 ‘totem’ tennis being played in the backyard
00:02:50:00 Stuart and a friend or cousin being rallied to pose for the camera
00:04:23:00 large family gathering in a park including a lovely group shot of grandchildren and greatgrandchildren with a grandparent
00:06:39:00 Stuart poses with a sports trophy
00:07:32:00 extended family wedding where Karen is a bridesmaid
00:08:30:00 Karen’s 21st birthday scenes where she and her brother wear matching red and white outfits and Dorothy is in a very smart dress that matches the theme
00:08:51 Karen shows off her birthday presents that are displayed on a table set up for the purpose
00:09:05:00 Karen and her new car

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film features tennis tournaments in Geelong, Ballarat and Shepparton, as well as horse riding at a family farm and attending the extended family weddings in Bellbrae and Geelong. A highlight is Karen’s 13th birthday.

Selected highights list:
00:00:38:00 Karen and Stuart in their uniforms, for Bells Park Primary School
00:02:20:00 the family enjoying their garden

00:06:02:00 a group of older women of the family smile for the camera
00:07:05:00 Dorothy and Stuart smile at the camera
00:07:40:00 water skiing on a river seen in the background, and swimmers in a swimming pool

00:08:50:00 Dorothy playing tennis

00:14:33:00 horse riding
00:19:00:00 family wedding featuring a fabulous example of a 1970s dress
00:19:23:00 a member of the bridal party sporting fabulous 1970s ‘sideburns’

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film is about family life in Geelong in the 1970s. Children Karen and Stuart have a ride on a motorbike, visits to the beach, to the ‘Bell Brae’ farm and to the snow, Karen’s 9th birthday party (filmed inside so quite dark), preparing for school, sports days and an extended family wedding. There are some great examples of 1970s fashion, particularly of the home made style.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 giving the children a ride on a motorcycle
00:00:20:00 family gathering sitting on the sand at the beach, eating ice creams
00:03:43:00 children surfing the waves
00:05:37:00 Karen’s nineth birthday party celebrations
00:05:55:00 the children riding their bikes around the house and the street, confident Karen waves to the camera
00:07:20:00 mother and daughter in the garden, Karen wearing ‘hotpants’ which were very popular in the 1970s
00:07:23:00 Karen poses for the camera in her ‘Brownies’ uniform
00:08:04:00 the grandparents of the family
00:08:58:00 Karen and Stuart ready for school
00:09:03:00 fishing off a pier
00:09:55:00 spectacular early 1970s hairstyles in preparation for one of the many family weddings
00:11:54:00 a family wedding in 1970s style
00:12:15:00 an extended family gathering
00:15:17:00 a visit to play in what might be sudden fall of snow
00:16:36:00 dad is wearing a 1970s ‘groovy’ outfit while posing with Karen and Stuart in the garden
00:17:07:00 Karen and companions do a ‘physical education’ display for the camera
00:17:57:00 Karen and Stuart pose with a blowup Santa in the garden
00:18:54:00 jet skiing at the beach

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film is a wonderful composite of the Nixon family’s life enjoying the company of their extended family at weddings, birthday gatherings and at the family holiday homes as well as on their travels to the Gold Coast, Queensland and Eildon Weir, Victoria. We see Karen turn six in the film as well as a great Christmas scene when both children are particularly excited to receive their presents, a watch for Karen and a scooter for Stuart.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 children on the beach at Portarlington
00:00:52:00 at a zoo
00:02:40:00 wedding with a tall headdress for the bride and bridesmaids in dark pink 1960s style dresses
00:04:10:00 Karen’s first day at school, in her uniform with school bag
00:04:24:00 Stuart on a trike (tricycle) saluting the camera
00:04:40:00 picnic on the beach with lots of extended family members
00:05:00:00 treasure hunt in the sand
00:06:54:00 the children on a farm tractor
00:07:20:00 the cousins of the family in a row at a driveway gate
00:08:19:00 Les, Karen and Stuart walking out of the water at the beach
00:09:49:00 children amusement park on ‘dodgem’ cars
00:11:26:00 Karen and Stuart being rowed in a rowboat, followed by a speedboat rushing past, very close to the shore
00:12:00:00 view of waterfront houses at the Gold Coast
00:12:10:00 TAA airplane taking off at an airport
00:13:27:00 extended family wedding with bridesmaids in what would have been (at the time) a very fashionable and wonderful burnt orange
00:15:28:00 Stuart receiving his Christmas scooter
00:16:00:00 Dorothy and daughter Karen in matching outfits
00:16:25:00 family members gathered under some shady trees at the beach
00:16:47:00 Karen very confidently ‘dinking’ her younger brother Stuart on his new scooter (by giving him a ride)
00:19:27:00 Dorothy and other women in the family laugh as they climb up, and fall on, a steep sand dune
00:20:13:00 Dorothy, Karen and Stuart stand outside their caravan at the beach
00:20:19:00 a family wedding, bridesmaids in purple and sporting some great examples of 1960s hairstyles
00:21:43:00 Karen’s sixth birthday party
00:22:27:00 Karen backstroking through the water
00:23:17:00 family picnic including a woman wearing a wonderful paisley shirt typical of fashion at the time
00:24:40:00 cooking on a vintage three-legged barbeque
00:26:00:00 a birthday party held at a holiday home possibly at Point Roadknight

description_for_label:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film is a wonderful composite of the Nixon family’s life enjoying the company of their extended family at weddings, birthday gatherings and at the family holiday homes as well as on their travels to the Gold Coast, Queensland and Eildon Weir, Victoria. We see Karen turn six in the film as well as a great Christmas scene when both children are particularly excited to receive their presents, a watch for Karen and a scooter for Stuart.

00:00:10:00 children on the beach at Portarlington
00:00:52:00 at a zoo
00:02:40:00 wedding with a tall headdress for the bride and bridesmaids in dark pink 1960s style dresses
00:04:10:00 Karen’s first day at school, in her uniform with school bag

00:04:40:00 picnic on the beach with lots of extended family members
00:05:00:00 treasure hunt in the sand
00:06:54:00 the children on a farm tractor
00:07:20:00 the cousins of the family in a row at a driveway gate
00:08:19:00 Les, Karen and Stuart walking out of the water at the beach
00:09:49:00 children amusement park on ‘dodgem’ cars
00:11:26:00 Karen and Stuart being rowed in a rowboat, followed by a speedboat rushing past, very close to the shore
00:12:00:00 view of waterfront houses at the Gold Coast
00:12:10:00 TAA airplane taking off at an airport
00:13:27:00 extended family wedding with bridesmaids in what would have been (at the time) a very fashionable and wonderful burnt orange
00:15:28:00 Stuart receiving his Christmas scooter
00:16:00:00 Dorothy and daughter Karen in matching outfits
00:16:25:00 family members gathered under some shady trees at the beach
00:16:47:00 Karen very confidently ‘dinking’ her younger brother Stuart on his new scooter (by giving him a ride)
00:19:27:00 Dorothy and other women in the family laugh as they climb up, and fall on, a steep sand dune
00:20:13:00 Dorothy, Karen and Stuart stand outside their caravan at the beach
00:20:19:00 a family wedding, bridesmaids in purple and sporting some great examples of 1960s hairstyles
00:21:43:00 Karen’s sixth birthday party

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film shows scenes of travelling around the Victorian countryside on motorcycles (motorbikes).

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 motorcycles being filmed from a vehicle travelling alongside
00:00:20:00 motorcycle rider with passenger wearing a beret
00:00:40:00 motorcycle riders gather for the camera at the Atlantic Garage in Ballarat
00:01:17:00 riding the motorcycles down a dusty road

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film captures Jack’s family and friends enjoying their scrambler motor bikes in muddy conditions at Korweinguboora, near Ballarat, Victoria. There are also visits to Geelong Racecourse and to Melbourne for some rowing races.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 a member of Jack’s circle on a motorbike
00:00:25:00 a group likely to be members of the Radio Cabs cooperative that Jack and Marie established in Ballarat
00:00:28:00 translucent title across the screen, ‘Ballarat Harley Club Mud Scrambles at Korweinguboora…’
00:00:39:00 riding the muddy track with sidecars
00:01:00:00 scrambling motorcycle riders
00:01:17:00 a fall in the mud for a motorcyclist
00:01:25:00 two stylishly dressed women pose for the camera
00:01:48:00 horses racing at Geelong Racecourse followed by the camera panning out over the Racecourse attendees from a higher vantage point
00:02:31:00 two men cycling through a quiet town street
00:03:01:00 two women and a man posing for the camera in front of the Eureka Stockade Memorial in what appears to be a cold wind
00:03:14:00 rowing races on a river
00:03:30:00 strolling through public gardens

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film features a parade of cars, trucks and buses in Ballarat and a visit to a swimming pool where Jack includes some special effects of diving into the pool. There is also a scene where two women are posing for the camera next to a car. It becomes evident that the older stately woman is shy of the camera but the endearing younger woman is very confident as she clowns around in her very 1940s trousers and beret outfit.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a parade of vehicles in Ballarat
00:00:50:00 two women stand in front of a car; one is joking around for the camera
00:01:05:00 at a swimming pool, a group of women onlookers watch a men diving into the water; the motion is reversed in a special effect so that we watch the diving in and back out of the pool
00:02:25:00 swimmers give an exhibition of the Australian Crawl (freestyle)

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Japan, Tahiti, New York and Funchal in Portugal. A feature of the film is a glimpse of what appears to be the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in New York when under construction.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a busy scene of junks sailing around a harbour, likely to be in Japan
00:00:30:00 for a large passenger ship being welcomed to port by a military band and Japanese geishas in costume
00:00:53:00 street scenes of a Japanese town, pagodas and historic buildings
00:01:43:00 a statue of an imposing looking man atop a rock formation
00:02:00:00 views of temples, traditional buildings and gardens
00:03:20:00 views of waterways, boats, ships, hills, some snow, and pagodas
00:06:20:00 view across the sea to some picturesque mountains in the background
00:07:37:00 some townhouses along the shoreline
00:08:01:00 a large passenger ship at a dock
00:08:38:00 the Stature of Liberty appears followed by the New York skyline
00:09:39:00 views of New York buildings including a glimpse of the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center during construction
00:09:55:00 a harbour view with ferries and piers and the Empire State Building in the background
00:11:20:00 a large tugboat chugs across the water
00:11:38:00 passengers on board a ship deck
00:13:28:00 Billy’s friends or relatives smile at the camera in a garden
00:14:29:00 a ship in port with some great cars of the era in the foreground
00:15:11:00 a public square and fountain, possibly in Portugal
00:16:26:00 decorative fishing boats being loaded in a port

William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to England during 1962 to 1964. On his travel Billy films views of London, English coastlines and towns, including Blackpool, Brighton and Coventry. A feature of this film is the Coventry Cathedral which Billy filmed, possibly when it was being consecrated in 1962. The Cathedral is significant as, having been almost destroyed during a Luftwaffe attack on Coventry in 1940, it was rebuilt in a deliberate modern design alongside the remains in 1956 and came to symbolise peace and reconciliation. The design by architect Sir Basil Spence included many artworks such as ‘St Michael’s defeat of the Devil’ by Jacob Epstein which can be seen in Billy’s film.

00:01:35:00 St Paul’s Cathedral

00:04:43:00 a large ferry
00:06:15:00 views around (most likely) the Royal Botanical Gardens Kew
00:07:12:00 spectators look at tulips in a public garden
00:07:45:00 views of an old church and cemetery
00:08:54:00 ‘Lady Godiva’ monument in Coventry, England
00:09:42:00 views around the Coventry Cathedral, including the artwork ‘St Michael’s defeat of the Devil’ on one of the Cathedral external walls
00:11:50:00 thatched houses
00:12:00:00 a very crowded beach scene
00:12:20:00 the Brighton Pavillon in Brighton, England
00:12:45:00 Arundel Castle in West Sussex, England
00:14:10:00 a carnival or street parade.
00:14:44:00 some lovely examples of trucks and buses of the era

00:15:32:00 a large ship and the ‘Liverpool Pilot’ vessel
00:15:45:00 an ‘Oyster and Prawn’ van in Blackpool, England
00:16:10:00 a look at a sandy populated beach from a higher vantage point
00:16:42:00 eating ice cream and cups of tea

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Peking (Beijing), China in 1960, filming cultivated fields, waterways, temples, public gardens and Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
